chapter.title: Guide to AAMA Documentation

para.remark: Note that at this point the documentation is in large part a lightly annotated set of lists progammatically generated from the output of a set of SPARQL queries, listing lexemes (output-. . . .rq[XREF]), morphosyntactic properties and values (output- . . . .rq[XREF], and a systematic index of paradigms (output-pdgmlabel-prop-val.rq [XREF]. Although we hope that this skeletal documentation will be helpful in finding and interpreting the data in the archive, it should be obvious what a distance there is between it and a morphological monograph or article. We trust that enough bibliography has been given to give the user a start on the more or less extensive literature that exists on each language.

chapter.para: Each language documentation will contain the following information:

sect2.title: Location-Speakers
sect2.para: The geographic location, estimated number of speakers, and attested varieties and subdialects of the language or language-variety in question. For the Cushitic-Omotic area, roughly the Horn of Africa and some adjacent areas in Sudan, Kenya, and Tanzania, a very helpful souce, and one usually linked to is the on-line Ethnologue catalogue, corrected or supplemented by other information, where necessary. The family-tree/genetic affliliation position assumed in the archive and presented in the systematic language index is not always identical with that of Ethnologue. Note that Ethnologue does not in principle offer coverage of ancient languages, and that other sources will be relied on and cited for those cases.

sect2.title: Bibliographic Source
sect2.para: Generally at this stage, the data from each language is taken from a single monographic source, whose reference is given in this section.

sect1.title: Paradigm Lexemes
sect1.para: Lemma and gloss of the lexical items which are used in the verbal paradigms.Where possible a single paradigm lexeme is used for each unique collection of morphosyntactic properties, including inflectional class. On occasion, the fragmentary nature of the documentation does not allow this. This is especially the case for dead languages, and for poorly or no longer attested varieties of living languages.

sect1.title: Morphosyntactic Properties

para.remark: To be added: more detail about unevenness of coverage, reason for not choosing noun paradigms; rationale for what gets included; somewhat arbitrary boundary between phonological and morphophonemic/morphological alternation -- especially in area of inflection classes [what is considered a phonological alternation in one source is a inflection class in another]. Notion of base paradigm -- the paradigms which were actually entered into the data-base; these must always be available in txt or xml form [HAVE TO DECIDE WHICH ONE IS NORMATIVE!].

sect1.para: This section of each language's data documentation contains a list of the morphosyntactic properties and their values used in the paradigms of the language in question. These are given in separate sections for the major part-of-speech paradigm sets, the pronominal and the varbal. In addition, a separate section is given for Person-Number-Gender (PNG) properties, which occupy a unique overlapping position between pronoun (often as defining properties) and verb (as the principal subject-agreement properties throughout the macro-family). Note that in many cases this section contains only an unannotated list of the paradigm properties (= row/col headings), each with a list of its values. As documentation proceeds on a language-by-language basis, theexplanation of the morphological paradigm dimensions with become (asymptotically) more complete.

Where necessary a word of explanation or an illustrative gloss will be given for properties or values whose sense is not immediately clear; this is a work in progress, and the amount of explanation or glossing will differ from language to language and from one release to another. In this context however it cannot be overemphasized that a set of labeled paradigms is not the morphology of a language but a tool for the exploration of that morphology, and that the present archive is not a comparative grammar of Cushitic-Omotic (or Afroasiatic), but a presentation of an important part of the data that such a grammar (or set of grammars) must account for -- and as well an implicit invitation to collect and organize whatever additional material might be necessary to make such a grammar possible. The labels and explanatory glosses given in the documentation and paradigm notes will hopefully give the user an idea, perhaps more or less precise according to his or her background, of the morphosyntactic properties and values involved in the morphology of a given language. But they are no substitute for the fuller presentation which will be found in each case in the source monograph, book or article.

Property-value associations will differ in detail from language to language. But there is a great similarity in their inventory across the archive, and a typical documentation page will usually approximate the following outline, which contains some property-values associations and comments on them which apply virtually across the whole range of Cushitic-Omotic languages, and which will be linked to from individual language data documentations.

listitem.para:
PNG includes, almost universally in Cushitic Omotic, the following properties and values:
number
singular sg
plural pl
person
first p1
second p2
thirs p3
gender
masculine m
feminine f

It should be noted that not all combinations of number, person, and gender acutally occur, and in fact, with a few notable exceptions (e.g., Beja) the prevailing PNG pattern in Cushitic and Omotic is:
number person gender
sg p1 "⊤"
sg p2 "⊤"
sg p3 m
sg p3 f
pl p1 "⊤"
pl p2 "⊤"
pl p3 "⊤"
I.e., where gender is distinguished only in the third-person singular. This pattern is so pervasive in Cushitic and Omotic that it will be referred to in the individual language documentation simply as the %-link linkend="cushOmPNG"-% Cushitic-Omotic PNG Pattern%-/link-%. PNG details will be given only when a language departs from this pattern. Note the symbol "⊤" ("down-tack", Unicode x22A4, logical "null:), which will be used in this archive for linguistic neutralization, in this case, of the gender distinction; i.e., sg-p1, sg-p2, and pl can be used in both masculine and feminine agreement contexts. For linguistic "null" the correlated symbol "⊥" (up-tack, Unicode x22A5) will be used.

case: The pronominal (and nominal) case system in most Cushitic(-Omotic) languages is of the "marked nominative (or subject)" type, wherein the subject of a clause is marked with a special suffix, as opposed to an unmarked "base (or absolutive)", which serves as citation form, direct object, and form to which oblique case postpositions are suffixed. There is often some way of expressing a possessive/genitive case, either by suffix or final vowel lengthening. As with PNG, this case pattern will be referred in in individual language documentation simply as the %-link linkend="cushOmCase"-% Cushitic-Omotic Case Pattern%-/link-%.
oblique: when given, will be with a list of oblique case postpositions (usually NP-final
type: This will be a list of the pronoun types attested in the various paradigms

itemizedlist.title: Verb Selector Properties: "Verb Selector" is a pre-verbal cliltic, or clitic chain which takes up, sometimes in a morphologically redundant fashion, sometimes not, a number of properties of the following verb. These properties differ from language to language, but often incllude pronominal subject markings, object parkings, and reference to verbal tense, aspect, and mood properties. The category, which is perhaps an areal one (cf. Bantu, from which the term derives), is limited (Oromo) or non-existent in more northerly Cushitic languages, fairly common in Omo-Tana, and highly developed in Southern Cushitic. Categories such as the following are common:

listitem.para: polarity: For the most part "affirmative" vs. "negative", although some variations and elaborations occur. It should be noted that few Cushitic-Omotic languages have negative forms of the simple additive type, whereby a verb is rendered negative by simple placement of a negative word, clitic, or affix next to the affirmative form of the verb. Negative forms, although they usually involve some negative formative, frequently have a distinct morphology, frequently with fewer tam or PNG distinctions than the affirmative. These restrictions for an individual language will usually be summarized in "Verb Properties" section, with details, if necessary, either under the polarity or the tense property sections.

theme: The theme or derived stem sections usually involve the following categories, and in most languages, combinations of these are possible: causative+causative (double causative) is very frequent, as are middle+causative, passive+causative, and causative+passive. Grammars differ widely in the extent to which all possible combinations are documented, and in some languages there are distinct differences among dialects, varieties, and even idiolects as to the acceptability of various theme combinations
causative: very frequently marked with prefix or suffix -s- (xref:: see below on prefixing and suffixing inflectional class)
middle/benefactive: often with prefix or suffix dental, voiced, voiceless, or retroflex (xref:: see below on prefixing and suffixing inflectional class)
passive: very frequently marked with prefix or suffix -m- (xref:: see below on prefixing and suffixing inflectional class)
composition: A subdistinction of %-link linkend="tam"-% Tense-Aspect-Mode%-/link-%

simple: Most Cushitic-Omotic languages have simple (lexical verb only) inflectional paradigms corresponding to the following categories, sometimes with a complementary distribution between the jussive (with no second person) and the imperative (second person only).

compound: Many, and perhaps most, Cushitic-Omotic lanuages have compound (lexical verb plus one or more peripheral auxiliary or clitic elements), yielding a much more detailed inventory of tense, aspect, and modal distinctions. The treatment of these varies widely in the archive sources. Some investigators give them perfunctory treatment, or even ignore them completely. Others furnish long series of compound paradigms, to a point where it becomes difficult to see where Verb+Aux leaves off and regular Verb+Complement constructions start -- a notorious problem in any case in the debate over the boundary between morphology and syntax. In this archive we will simply reproduce the distinctions made in the source document. Since many of these distinctions are (morpho-)syntactically and semantically quite complex, in addition to the name, in the annotation I will simply give a translational paraphrase, and refer the user to the original source for more complete discussion. Typical compound paradigm categories are:

inflectionClass: as in all languages, phonological and grammaticization processes conspire to create more or less marked morphophonemic differences in the verbal inflections of different sets of verbs.

affixationClass: Cross-cutting normal inflectional class in some branches of Cushitic (Beja and Omo-Tana, perhaps also Agaw) is an archaic Afroasiatic distinction between prefix conjugations (where the PNG subject markers are at least partially prefixed, and tam distinctions can be marked by internal vowel change) and suffix conjugations (where PNG subject markers are totally suffixed, and the verb base is invariant). It should be noted that , as opposed to Semitic, where this formal distinction corresponds to a tense-aspect distinction (past/non-past, perfective/imperfective) in all verbs, in the Cushitic languages which preserve it, this distinction is lexical, and a given verb-base is conjugated completely either in the prefix or the suffix pattern. Note further that in all Cushitic languages the productive pattern is the suffix-conjugation: only Beja and Saho-Afar have large numbers of prefix-conjugated verbs, and in the Omo-Tana languages the prefix-conjugated class is limited to a small inventory of at most a couple dozen high-frequency lexical items
special: almost every language has one or more infledctionally exceptional class of verbs, frequently involving the expression of "to be" in one or more of its senses and "to have"
